paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper discusses variants in the TTR gene associated with hereditary transthyretin amyloidosis, detailing clinical significance, penetrance data, and individual patient information.

patients.demographics: 6 males, 3 females, mean age 54 years (range 44–64 years), all Koreans of East Asian descent

individual_records.phenotype_details: mixed type, vitreous opacity, orthostatic hypotension, diarrhea
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient No. 1 with the longest duration of illness and severe neuropathic symptoms (PND score of 3b) among all participants had the lowest, near-normal result in the total score.
Patient No. 2 had a mixed type presentation with no ocular manifestations.
Patient No. 3 had a neuropathy type amyloidosis.

individual_records.phenotype_details: mixed type, vitreous opacity, orthostatic hypotension, diarrhea
individual_records.evidence_sentence: Patient No. 4 had vitreous opacity due to amyloid deposits.
Patient No. 5 had a mixed type presentation with no ocular manifestations.
Patient No. 6 was an asymptomatic carrier.
Patient No. 7 had a mixed type presentation with no ocular manifestations.
Patient No. 8 had a mixed type presentation with no ocular manifestations.

functional_data.summary: The study evaluated nailfold capillaroscopy (NFC) outcomes in patients with TTR mutations.

variants.segregation_data: The variants segregate with disease in families.
variants.additional_notes: The asymptomatic carrier showed the highest score in NFC, indicating severe impairment despite being unaffected.
key_quotes: All eight patients had peripheral neuropathy, and five of them had additional neuropathology limited to the hand called CTS.
The asymptomatic carrier (Patient No. 6) showed the lowest capillary density or highest avascular areas in NFC and had the highest score of 6.125.

tables_processed.table_caption: Clinical characteristics and nailfold capillography of participants.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data was extracted from the main text and tables.
